description: From Middle English soile, soyle, sule (â€œground, earthâ€), partly from Anglo-Norman soyl (â€œbottom, ground, pavementâ€), from Latin solium (â€œseat, chair; throneâ€), mistaken for Latin solum (â€œground, foundation, earth, sole of the footâ€); and partly from Old English sol (â€œmud, mire, wet sandâ€), from Proto-Germanic *sulÄ… (â€œmud, spotâ€), from Proto-Indo-European *sÅ«l- (â€œthick liquidâ€). Cognate with Middle Low German sÃ¶le (â€œdirt, mudâ€), Middle Dutch sol (â€œdirt, filthâ€), Middle High German sol, sÃ¶l (â€œdirt, mud, mireâ€), Danish sÃ¸le (â€œmud, muckâ€). Compare French seuil (â€œlevel; thresholdâ€) and sol (â€œsoil, earth; groundâ€). See also sole, soal, solum.

entries.meaning: (uncountable) A mixture of mineral particles and organic material, used to support plant growth.
examples: We bought a bag of soil for the houseplants.

entries.meaning: (uncountable) The unconsolidated mineral or organic material on the immediate surface of the earth that serves as a natural medium for the growth of land plants.

(uncountable) The unconsolidated mineral or organic matter on the surface of the earth that has been subjected to and shows effects of genetic and environmental factors of: climate (including water and temperature effects), and macro- and microorganisms, conditioned by relief, acting on parent material over a period of time. A product-soil differs from the material from which it is derived in many physical, chemical, biological, and morphological properties and characteristics.

examples: Except during the season in town, she spends her year in golfing, either at St Magnus or Pau, for, like all good Americans, she has long since abjured her native soil.

entries.meaning: That which soils or pollutes; a stain.
A marshy or miry place to which a hunted boar resorts for refuge; hence, a wet place, stream, or tract of water, sought for by other game, as deer.

description: From Middle English soilen, soulen, suylen (â€œto sully, make dirtyâ€), partly from Old French soillier, souillier (â€œto soil, make dirty, wallow in mireâ€), from Old Frankish *sauljan, *sulljan (â€œto make dirty, soilâ€); partly from Old English solian, sylian (â€œto soil, make dirtyâ€), from Proto-Germanic *sulwÅnÄ…, *sulwijanÄ…, *saulijanÄ… (â€œto soil, make dirtyâ€), from Proto-Indo-European *sÅ«l- (â€œthick liquidâ€). Cognate with Old Frisian sulia (â€œto soil, mireâ€), Middle Dutch soluwen, seulewen (â€œto soil, besmirchâ€), Old High German solÅn, bisulen (â€œto make dirtyâ€), German suhlen (â€œto soil, make dirtyâ€), Danish sÃ¸le (â€œto make dirty, defileâ€), Swedish sÃ¶la (â€œto soil, make dirtyâ€), Gothic ğŒ±ğŒ¹ğƒğŒ°ğŒ¿ğŒ»ğŒ¾ğŒ°ğŒ½ (bisauljan, â€œto bemireâ€). Compare sully.

entries.meaning: (uncountable, euphemistic) Faeces or urine etc. when found on clothes.
(countable, medicine) A bag containing soiled items.

verbs.description: soil (third-person singular simple present soils, present participle soiling, simple past and past participle soiled)

examples: Light colours soil sooner than dark ones.

entries.meaning: (transitive, figurative) To stain or mar, as with infamy or disgrace; to tarnish; to sully.
(reflexive) To dirty one's clothing by accidentally defecating while clothed.
examples: The child was so scared she soiled herself.

entries.meaning: To enrich with soil or muck; to manure.

description: From Middle English soyl, from Old French soil, souil (â€œquagmire, marshâ€), from Frankish *sÅlja, *saulja (â€œmire, miry place, wallowâ€), from Proto-Germanic *saulijÅ (â€œmud, puddle, fecesâ€), from Proto-Indo-European *sÅ«l- (â€œthick liquidâ€). Cognate with Old English syle, sylu, sylen (â€œmiry place, wallowâ€), Old High German sol, gisol (â€œmiry placeâ€), German Suhle (â€œa wallow, mud pit, muddy poolâ€).

entries.meaning: A wet or marshy place in which a boar or other such game seeks refuge when hunted.

description: From Old French saoler, saouler (â€œto satiateâ€).

verbs.description: soil (third-person singular simple present soils, present participle soiling, simple past and past participle soiled)

entries.meaning: To feed, as cattle or horses, in the barn or an enclosure, with fresh grass or green food cut for them, instead of sending them out to pasture; hence (due to such food having the effect of purging them) to purge by feeding on green food.
